title: 107_hr2498
content: The Rent-To-Own Reform Act of 2001, also known as the Rent-To-Own Protection Act, amends the Consumer Credit Protection Act by adding a new title specifically for rent-to-own transactions. It includes provisions for definitions, application of state and federal laws, disclosures, prohibitions, enforcement, civil liability, regulations, and relationship to other laws. The Rent-To-Own Reform Act of 2001 aims to address issues in the rent-to-own industry, targeting low-income and minority neighborhoods. Customers often intend to own the goods they rent, but dealers fail to disclose key contract terms and engage in unfair practices. Customers lack protections provided in retail sales, facing excessive fees and interest rates. The Act seeks to provide consumers with necessary legal protections in rent-to-own transactions. The Rent-To-Own Reform Act of 2001 aims to provide legal protections for consumers in rent-to-own transactions. It includes requirements for disclosure of contract terms, prohibits abusive collection practices, and ensures consumers' right to terminate agreements. The Rent-To-Own Reform Act of 2001 aims to provide legal protections for consumers in rent-to-own transactions, including requirements for disclosure of contract terms, prohibiting abusive collection practices, and ensuring consumers' right to terminate agreements. SEC. 1003 defines key terms. The Rent-To-Own Reform Act of 2001 aims to protect consumers in rent-to-own transactions by defining key terms such as 'Board' and 'cash price'. The 'Board' refers to the Federal Reserve System's Board of Governors, while 'cash price' is the retail price paid in full before possession of an item or service. The Rent-To-Own Reform Act of 2001 defines key terms such as 'consumer' and 'credit'. 'Consumer' refers to an individual using items for personal purposes, while 'credit' includes the right to possess goods under a rent-to-own contract before full payment. The Rent-To-Own Reform Act of 2001 defines the total amount required for ownership acquisition in a rent-to-own contract, excluding certain fees and charges. A rent-to-own contract is a terminable lease agreement. The Rent-To-Own Reform Act of 2001 defines a rent-to-own contract as a terminable lease or bailment of consumer goods where the consumer has the right of possession and use, with the option to renew the contract by making specified payments. The seller agrees to transfer ownership upon fulfillment of all consumer obligations. The term 'seller' refers to a person who regularly provides consumer goods under rent-to-own contracts and to whom payments are due. The term 'State' includes any state, Puerto Rico, the District of Columbia, and any U.S. territory or possession. SEC. 1004. Application of state laws regarding fees, charges, guarantees, and warranties to rent-to-own transactions. In rent-to-own transactions, sellers are prohibited from charging interest, finance charges, or fees that exceed the limits set by the laws of the state where the seller is located. This includes restrictions on interest rates, fees, and credit insurance premiums for similar credit or retail sales. In rent-to-own transactions, sellers can charge termination fees and reasonable fees for recovery of items not returned voluntarily upon termination. In rent-to-own transactions, sellers can charge termination fees not exceeding 5% of the cash price, disclosed in the contract, and calculated as part of the finance charge. Recovery fees must also be disclosed in the contract. In rent-to-own transactions, termination fees not exceeding 5% of the cash price can be charged to the consumer. The termination fee satisfies the consumer's obligation for all payments and fees under the contract, except for fees due before termination. Guarantees and warranties required by state laws for goods sold in consumer credit sales also apply to goods in rent-to-own transactions. "Federal laws apply to rent-to-own transactions, including guarantees and warranties required by state laws for goods sold in consumer credit sales." The Truth in Lending Act, Equal Credit Opportunity Act, and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act apply to rent-to-own transactions. The Fair Credit Reporting Act applies to credit transactions and the extension or denial of credit, treating payments owed as debt. "SEC. 1006. DISCLOSURES." The seller must provide specific information on each item available for purchase in a rent-to-own transaction, including the cash price, itemized services, annual percentage rate, payment schedule, and total payments required for ownership. Upon entering a rent-to-own contract, the seller must provide written information to the consumer about the item being purchased, including whether it is new or used. SEC. 1007. PROHIBITIONS AND ENFORCEMENT. Prohibitions under a rent-to-own contract include not threatening criminal prosecution, using coercion to collect payments, harassing consumers, disclosing information to third parties, or engaging in fraudulent behavior. Prohibited actions under a rent-to-own contract include making fraudulent representations, using unconscionable means to collect debts, falsely advertising services as free, and using incorrect definitions for terms like 'cash price'. The Federal Trade Commission enforces compliance with regulations related to rent-to-own transactions, prohibiting unfair or deceptive practices. The Federal Trade Commission enforces regulations on rent-to-own transactions, treating violations as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Board and the Federal Trade Commission issue necessary regulations to implement and prohibit specific seller practices. The Federal Trade Commission will issue regulations to implement subsection (b). "SEC. 1008. CIVIL LIABILITY." Any seller failing to disclose terms under section 1006 is liable to the consumer for actual damages, $250 for each failure, and legal fees. For violations of this title or other requirements, the seller is liable for actual damages, $2,500 per violation, and legal fees. An action under this title can be filed in any US district court within 24 months of the violation. This does not prevent a person from asserting a violation more than 2 years later as a defense in a collection action. The Rent-To-Own Reform Act of 2001 applies to rent-to-own contracts entered into after regulations are issued by the Board. It does not apply to motor vehicle leases or sales subject to the Truth in Lending Act. The Board must issue necessary regulations within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The Rent-To-Own Reform Act of 2001 does not override state laws regarding rent-to-own transactions, except where there is inconsistency. Consumer lease provisions of the Truth in Lending Act do not apply to rent-to-own transactions, except for motor vehicle leases or sales.
